Q1_C1: Power analysis
I will use a power analysis or go with the at-least-30-participants-per-condition rule.
The design of the experiment; the time of year (i.e., end of the semester);

Q1_C2: Based on power analysis and feasibility constraints with any given population

Q1_C1: Statistical power
I adopt the rule of thumb to try to guarantee at least 30 subjects per condition. Though, where possible I try together data from as many subjects as are available.
Power analysis in advance, before I recruit my participants.

I usually aim for 20 - 25 participants per cell of the experimental design, which is typically what it takes to detect a medium effect size with .80 probability.  My answer to the next question is based on the assumption that the experiment would be a standard two-cell design.
By a practical balance with practical constraints (i.e. available founding), and expected sample size to detect the effect of interest.
Power analysis such that I have an 80% chance or better of detecting my target effect size.
power analysis, pre-experiments
Power analysis, or look at how much data is required in order to get stable parameter estimates for the model of interest.
Power Analysis and examination of what is done in published research studies on the same topic.

Q1_C2: I look at whether there's a power analysis, and the power analysis was appropriately done (not coming up with a tortured justification for as small a sample size as possible)

Q1_C1: My ideal N is always based on an estimate of the effect size, and the alpha and beta errors I consider as adequate. The actual N however is often smaller due to restrictions in terms of participant money, participants available and lab space.

Q1_C2: Recently, journal published by the Psychonomic Society requires that submitted papers include a power analysis. I think that is a very wise decision; as a reviewer I take critical look at the power calculation (if such a calculation is available). In addition, it would be good if researchers could focus on the desired precision of the effect they are going to estimate in their study (see Geff Cumming).

Q1_C1: I use secondary  data analysis of large-scale longitudinal data (N >5000) for virtually all my research

Q1_C2: There is no easy answer. This depends on the kind of study, the methods, the design, the field, the subject looked at, and the aim of the study. E.g. a clinical study assessing a rare desease could be great with only 10 participants, while for a simple questionnaire in a wide field 100 participants might be not enough.  /  / The same answer holds true for your next question: The "between subjects design" does not tell me enough of the background of the study/studies to decide. I am very sorry that I have to give an answer-therefore please consider this answer as "not given"!

Q1_C1: I typically conduct an a prior power analysis. From there I collect as many subjects as I can. I work at a small university, so this often takes multiple semesters. Additionally, I do look at my data at the end of each semester and, if minimum sample sizes have been reached (at least n = 20 per cell) and the effects I am looking for are there, I will stop data collection.
power analysis evt. based on pilot study /
Using the convention established by others

Q1_C2: Depending on the design of the study, using categorical or continuous variables, I assess N < 20 (per cell) as a small sample size.

I look at A) whether it meets field-accepted standards (e.g. 16 per cell in infant work), B) at measures of variability, e.g. SD, C) at measures of estimate precision (SEM/95% CI), and at ability to fit the appropriate model (e.g. regression).

Q1_C1: I have tried to replicate the higher sample size used in similar studies

Q1_C2: By looking at the N, the p-value and the effect size.

Q1_C1: Power, availability, past levels of attrition.
I work with large available databases and based on the research question I conduct a power analysis

Q1_C2: I try to estimate a reasonable effect size from the literature and then see if the sample size in question had a reasonable chance of detecting that effect.  All other things being equal, a correlation of .20 is not a bad point estimate.  So hopefully the sample could detect that size correlation.  I get nervous about complex interactions and would like to see much larger samples than most people use.

I think sample size is rather a quantitative aspect than a qualitative, in the sense that a larger sample is more likely to provide conclusive evidence. I would even favour a smaller study, if the overall design is better. For example in many contexts, a representative sample of 200 is clearly prefereable to a convenience sample (say of university students) of size 400. /  / In general, I would base all sample size considerations on a priori power calculations. /  / PS: the second question is a bit confusing. Do you mean "5 arms" when you mean "5 studies"? Or do you mean "5 replications" of the same experiment? I took it to mean "5 studies" in the sense of independent replications like in a meta-analysis.
It depends on the journal and the amount of information provided. IN journals like Psych Science, it is impossible to assess it - I base it on the general norms in the field.

Q1_C1: I carry out simulations, rather than with individuals. The simple size should be as large as posible; power analysis are relevant for statistical signifcance only, but not for effect sizes.

Experimental studies with expected large effects, I normally choose n = 20 per cell.  For moderate effects, I normally choose n = 30 per cell.  For correlational studies, I normally aim for at least 100 participants.

Q1_C2: If information is provided on the estimated size of the effect that the study is testing (which it almost never is), I assess the sample relative to the N needed to find effects of that size.  I also assess the sample in the context of the type of study.  For example, for a questionnaire study on undergrads I would expect a much larger sample size than a 2-year longitudinal fMRI study on anxious children (b/c it's harder to get/retain participants over time, it's harder to get anxious children, and the cost of fMRI is higher).  The reason I do so is that, for some study types, it would be prohibitive to get the large sample size that we'd all like.  Thus, for this research to be done at all, I think we can accept a lower standard.  In addition, b/c the cost of such studies is so high (even for small samples), it tends to exclude more junior researchers (b/c only established researchers with large grants have the resources).   /  / For the sake of transparency, I should note that I'm a junior researcher who studies clinical populations and adolescents with fMRI (and sometime longitudinally).

Q1_C1: Based first on effect size and power which can usually be found in prior research published. Second consideration is feasibility which factors in recruitment timetable and cost.
Power analysis
Use G*Power to determine the sample size large enough to detect the "average" effect size in social/personality research, i.e. .3.

Q1_C2: it mainly depends on the sample characteristics: more is (almost always) better, but that may be more difficult with certain populations or certain research designs.

Q1_C1: In advance based on previous research indicative of likely effect sizes

Q1_C2: Compare it to similar studies & take into account the sample size requirements of the respective statistical analyses
Based on rules of thumb and common sense.

Q1_C1: In the past, I have always assumed at least 100 participants. Now I shoot for that number.

I target N = 200 if I can get it; try not to fall below 120. These numbers, I have found, offer sufficient power to detect effects at p < .05 that are also of practical significance in the areas in which I do research.
I perform a-priori power analyses
It is usually based on how many participants we manage to get based on our available resources, such as the availability of credit subjects and funding.
Most usually by reference to previous studies using the same or similar paradigms.

Q1_C2: The weaker the effect the higher the sample size must be. If authors report a clear significant effect, n = 20 is sufficient.

I consider a number of factors--effect sizes, measurement quality and reliability, and type of analysis. I also consider whether the authors are making strong or weak empirical claims, whether they are reporting new effects versus replications, and whether they are focusing on significant or non-significant tests (e.g., ruling out a certain effect).
yes

Q1_C1: I make a quick calculation but our sample sizes are also influenced by the availability of the participants that we need
Either a power analysis based on earlier studies that used the same experiment or the same sample size as in earlier studies that used the same manipulation (for instance pharmacological challenge).

Q1_C2: standard deviations and standard errors compared to what I'd expect for reasonable differences between means given the tested theory
For between-subject designs are sample should not be too small (<50), but replication within one study is better than a higher total sample

Q1_C1: Guidelines and sample size calculation (GPower)
power analysis

If designing a fresh study, try to have a min of 200 participants, which provides 80% power to detect an effect comparable to a correlation of .20. In web studies, we typically just leave a survey/study online until we're ready to deal with it. This leads to variable (and large) sample sizes, but the number isn't pre-determined. In many studies we're analyzing data from longitudinal datasets not designed by our team; we have no control over those N's.
With help from Statisticians

Q1_C2: Haven't reviewed

Q1_C2: power analysis, assumed effect size
Power analysis if possible

Power analysis
I base on the experimental conditions, using the heuristic of  at least 20 participants per cell. For example, for a 2x2, I would need at least 80 participants.

Q1_C2: When non-significance is taken to invalidate hypotheses, I guesstimate the power of the study and when unclear ask authors to consider power more carefully.

Q1_C1: No formal power analysis.  I select a sample size usually based on my past experience of what size sample is necessary for either (a) finding significance with an effect size in the range of r = .20 to .25, or (b) conducting the type of analysis that is plannec (i.e. about N = 300 for exploratory factor analysis).

Q1_C2: the bigger the better.

Q1_C1: According to common practices in the field, and power analysis.

Q1_C2: As a trade-off.   /  / I generally prefer larger sample sizes, since there is a lower risk of the study capitalizing on chance.  With large sample sizes, you can look at whether the effect size (likely with a narrower CI around the point) is substantial or trivial, and worry less about whether it hits a magic threshold value of p. /  / However, I understand that in my field (organizational psychology), there are often hard-to-reach, real-world populations.  I am not going to reject a paper that has 80 CEOs as experimental participants simply because it's a bit underpowered.  I think this is where it is nice to pair cheap, easy participants (a very large mTurk sample, or a huge intro-psych-pool sample) to demonstrate the effect, then replicate it with a smaller sample of the population of interest. /  / In complete honesty as a reviewer, though, sample size doesn't often figure heavily in my review.  On occasion, I've fired up g*Power and noted something about the achieved power, especially if there's a surprisingly tiny cell size in a design that might be expected to have small effect sizes... but it doesn't come up too frequently.
Typically by Simonsohn's rules about cell size; if correlational, usually want to see at least N of 150. Typically unconvinced by single study papers, though. /
really depends

Q1_C1: A prior power analysis based on estimated or published effect sizes.

Availability and power analysis. Our research focuses on cancer patients so there is often a limit as to how many we can recruit/enroll in a specific time frame.

A sample size with fewer than 20 participants per cell causes concern. Consistent sample sizes throughout the paper of fewer than 30 per cell triggers concern.

Q1_C2: Based on a number of considerations related to the hypotheses in question, whether author included a power analysis with submission, anticipated effect size, replication vs exploratory analyses, plus heuristics related to type of study and whether known problem with type II error (e.g., candidate gene association studies).
power analysis based on the proposed methods

Q1_C2: It would depend on the size of the effect. I think sample size has to be big enough (n > 30 or so), but if a paper replicates an effect in a second sample, then sample size becomes less important. A small N with significant results would cue to me that it's a strong effect.

Q1_C1: Power-analysis based on effect size estimates. Estimates are based on past experiences.

Q1_C2: I prefer a minimum n = 30 per cell. More is better. Anything less is insufficient.
The optimal sample size depends on the effect that researchers aim to find. Thus, as a reviewer, I positively value a priori sample size calculations based on an appropriate power analysis.

Q1_C1: Whenever possible, power analysis based on pilot data.

Assuming that this is pertaining to collection of new data and not archival data, I determine the sample size by trying to estimate effect sizes and see what sample is needed to be powerful enough to detect that magnitude of an effect, reviewing other studies' sample sizes (assuming relevant studies exist), and then there are practical constraints that sometimes may constrain sample size (e.g., specific mental disorder is less often diagnosed in my local area than estimated prior to data collection).

Q1_C2: It depends on many different factors such as the reported effect size or the research design.

Q1_C1: power analysis to determine sample size required to detect effects of various size
rules of thumb for between, within, and mixed model designs and number of factors.

Q1_C2: If it fits a general estimate of what I think is adequate

Q1_C1: It depends on the methodology, previously observed effect size, and subject population. Noisier subjects (e.g. children) or smaller expected effects require a larger N. If effect size is unknown, I estimate it by looking at an initial subset of data (I realize that 'data peeking' is frowned upon, but if the effect size is unknown, there's no other way). I then maintain the same sample size throughout a series of studies.
use past literature as an initial guide, but also try for at least 30 per cell of a between-subjects design.

As a reviewer I hope that the authors have chosen a sample size with sufficient power. I give the authors some latitude if the study is a pure exploratory study so the effect sizes are unknown.

i read the sample description in the methods section, and evaluate the sample's suitability through my expertise in research. if i find the sample description incomplete, or the sample inadequate, i raise this issue in my review.

Quality sample size is dependent upon the size of the effect the investigators wish to demonstrate as well as on the nature of the research question. For example, study of a rare disorder may prevent very large samples.
The main issue in sample size would be statistical power--i.e., if the authors obtained a non-significant result with a small sample, I would question the possibility of a type II error.
An N of fewer than 20 per cell is pretty much unacceptable. The sample size may vary somewhat depending on the difficulty of the study, but generally I like to see at least 40-50 people per cell.
looking at effect sizes

Q1_C2: Coming from the social sciences I first evaluate sampling design (i.e. probability sampling, etc); sample size is secondary to that. I generally do not review small sample size studies, especially not when non-probability designs, i.e. I reject invitations to review them.

Until recently, I don't think I thought much about this--and usually it's not much of an issue in papers I end up reviewing. But on average, I'm mostly concerned about basing conclusions on small samples, especially when a paper does not attempt to replicate a finding across experiments. Very large samples with small effects are also suspicious, especially if sample size fluctuate across experiments (i.e., could be a sign of p-hacking). But I don't think that's come up in a paper I've reviewed.

We have a lab that we use. Typically about 100-250 people sign up for each lab session, and I do not know in advance how many people will participate. I run studies in one and one only session. I never stop studies (unless there is an error in its operationalization) and never double up on sessions.

Depends upon research design.  For basic correlational studies I aim for 100+, but this would go upwards depending upon the specific hypotheses, analyses appropriate for testing the hypotheses, and so forth.  For example, multiple regressions with many variables and some interactions, I would aim for larger sample size.   For experiments, I generally aim for 30+ per condition.  However, for exact estimates for specific study designs, I would calculate desired power, estimated sample size, etc.

Q1_C2: Based on my experience of potential effect size and power to find the effect. Coupled with known issues that can affect a reasonable expected sample size (e.g., in a clinical setting)

Q1_C1: I used to base my sample size on the heuristic: 15-20 participants per cell / Nowadays I standardly conduct poweranalysis to determine sample size
power analyses / practicability

Q1_C2: Mostly, I would look for a reasonable ratio of sample size vs number of conditions, and a roughly even distribution between conditions. I prefer larger samples to threadbare ones, though truly excessive samples should be avoided.

Q1_C1: it depends on the resources available. For a lab study at least 20-30  participants per condition (although the study suffers from low power it is difficult to get more participants in the lab)

Q1_C2: Sample size should be looked at in function of the research question. For example if it is a qualitative or quantitative study sample sizes can vary substantially. For quantitative studies that involve multilevel data one should look at the variation in sample sizes at multiple levels. Usually, I am also concerned when sample sizes become too large in quantitative studies because their power levels become too high.

Q1_C2: I try to determine whether it is sufficient for the proposed analyses.  I also like to know whether it might be representative of some population.

Sample size requirements vary depending on the design of the study.  Some analyses require larger samples than others to provide sufficient power for hypothesis testing.  I consider the type of analyses, reported findings, and power calculations to evaluate quality of the sample size.

availability and sample size calculation (power)

Q1_C2: I estimate power based on total N, type of analysis, expected effect size, and number of cells.

Q1_C1: For the effects that I typically study, I know that 24 to 36 participants per condition is reasonable. I base the exact number of participants upon the number of variables that need to be counterbalanced (to ensure that there are an equal number of people in each counterbalanced condition).

Q1_C2: I work in developmental psychology, in infancy work, where sample sizes are often quite low (under 50, sometimes as small as 24).
If it's appropriate for the model under consideration and is likely to have a chance to be representative of the population from which it was derived.

As a reviewer I adhere to the recommendations of Simmons, Nelson & Simonsohn, 2011. I look for an n of at least 20 per condition (although that is still terribly low for detecting most effects we study). I also look for a concrete statement as to how that n was determined.

Q1_C1: I have basic rules of thumb born out of experience in my area. Sometimes will do power analyses.

Q1_C2: In general I look to see that the sample size is consistent with previous studies within that field. For example, genetics findings tend to have small effects and large sample sizes. For cognitive neuroscience fMRI studies I might expect between 15-25 subjects. For studies on the sensory systems I might anticipate at least 8 subjects.
past research

Q1_C1: I look to other, similar studies, or to my own past work and calculate the number of participants necessary to achieve power =.80 given alpha =.05.
Based on previous similar studies, samples availability, and rough estimate of the effect size

Q1_C2: By assessing its power to find its hypothesized effects.
convention in the field + power analysis + what conclusions are being drawn (if sample size is smaller but conclusions are more tentative that's acceptable)

Q1_C1: the minimal sample size is usually determined by considering the size of the effects of interest
My research is largely focused on a longitudinal sample, so the sample size is determined the number of participants who have been retained across the years.

Q1_C2: Depends on the expected size and confidence intervals of the effect. Example: Sample size of 100 is sufficient for g-loadings of Wechsler subtests, but at least 400 twin pairs would be required for reasonably accurate heritability estimates.

Q1_C1: I aim to get around 40 participants for each condition. For correlational studies, I will try to get at least 100 participants.
